Class IntEquRelation

java.lang.Object
IntRelation
IntEquRelation
Direct Known Subclasses:
IntEquRelationArrays, IntEquRelationSetOfSets
public abstract class IntEquRelation
extends IntRelation
An IntEquRelation object maintains an equivalence relation on small integers. The relation is a subset of [0..n) x [0..n), where n, called the extent of the relation, is given in the constructor and is immutable. There are operations to test membership, to retrieve the equivalence class of an element, and to add pairs

Model: subset of [0..extent()) x [0..extent())

Author:
Loek Cleophas / Tom Verhoeff (TU/e)
Invariant:
(NonNegativeExtent: 0 <= extent()) && (ReflexiveRelation: (\forall i; 0 <= i < extent(); areRelated(i, i))) && (SymmetricRelation: (\forall i, j; areRelated(i, j); areRelated(j, i))) && (TransitiveRelation: (\forall i, j, k; areRelated(i, j) && areRelated(j, k); areRelated(i, k)))

  • Constructor Details

    • IntEquRelation

      public IntEquRelation​(int n) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Constructs an empty equivalence relation of given extent.
      Parameters:
      n - extent of the new equivalence relation
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if n < 0
      Precondition:
      0 <= n
      Postcondition:
      this is the identity relation on [0..extent()) (the smallest equivalence relation on this set).

      public abstract void add​(int a, int b) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Adds a pair to the equivalence relation.
      Specified by:

      Parameters:
      a - first element of the pair to add

      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if ! isValidPair(a, b)
      Precondition:
      isValidPair(a, b)
      Modifies:
      this, but not this.extent()
      Postcondition:
      this is the minimal extension of \old(this) union [ (a, b) ] such that this is an equivalence relation
